Award.AwardTitle: K-theory of Operator Algebras and its Applications to Geometry and Topology
Award.AbstractNarration:
The investigator proposes to study the K-theory of group C*-algebras and its applications to geometry and topology of manifolds. The K-theory of group C*-algebras are receptacles of higher indices of elliptic differential operators and have important applications to problems in differential geometry and topology of manifolds such as the existence problem for Riemannian metrics with positive scalar curvature and the Novikov conjecture on homotopy invariance of higher signatures. The methods to be employed include group actions on Banach spaces, uniform embedding into Banach spaces, and infinite dimensional index theory of elliptic operators.
Manifolds are spaces glued together by Euclidean spaces. Roughly speaking, these are spaces on which one can do calculus. Examples of manifolds inlcude spheres and tori. Manifold theory plays an important role in mathematics and physics. A fundamental problem in manifold theory is the classification of manifolds. By surgery theory, the classification problem for higher dimensional manifolds is essentially reduced to the Novikov conjecture. The investigator plans to study the Novikov conjecture using methods from infinite dimensional analysis such as noncommutative geometry. The investigator also intends to apply noncommutative geometry methods to study analysis on loop spaces of manifolds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Manifolds are geometric objects glued together by Euclidean spaces. They play an important role in mathematics and physics such as Einstein's theory of relativity.

Geometry and topology of manifolds are governed by certain differential equations. A fundamental invariant of these differential equations is called higher index. Roughly speaking the higher index measures the size of the solution spaces of these differential equations. The PI and his collaborators have computed the higher index of these differential equations in many cases including certain generic cases called expanders.

Classification of manifolds is a fundamental problem in mathematics. The PI and his collaborators introduced a theory of geometric complexity and succeeded in the stable classification of manifolds under the finite geometric complexity condition. The Novikov conjecture claims that manifolds are rigid at certain infinitesimal level. The PI and his collaborators have proved the Novikov conjecture under very general condition. This work also establishes a new connection between several mathematical subjects including topology of manifolds, geometric group theory, nonlinear Banach space geometry,  and noncommutative geometry.

The PI  has  been actively involved with the training of next generation mathematicians by organizing an annual noncommutative geometry school, supervising five PhD students, three postdocs and several REU students. The PI has given numerous lectures including several minicourses designed for graduate students.
